vectorData.altText: That's right!  The thoracic duct is between the azygous vein and thoracic aorta and it is posterior to the esophagus, which is reflected in this image.
That is incorrect. Click here     to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
Between the azygous vein and the thoracic aorta, IDENTIFY:
the thoracic duct.  Because the thoracic duct is posterior to the esophagus, it might be helpful to have a colleague retract the esophagus to the left.

The thoracic duct is roughly the size of a probe tip. Carefully clean the thoracic duct along its length to where it passes behind the diaphragm with the thoracic aorta; it is thin-walled and easily torn. 
Notice that it has many small swellings along its length, making it look like a small vein. Indeed, these swellings are formed by the numerous valves located along its length, that ensure the movement of lymph superiorly, toward the terminus of the thoracic duct at the left venous angle. 
Make note of the relationship of the thoracic duct to the right posterior intercostal arteries, arising from the thoracic aorta, and the hemiazygous and accessory hemiazygous veins: the thoracic duct runs anterior to these structures.
